document.masterDocTitle: Velvet ants of the tribe Smicromyrmini Bischoff (Hymenoptera: Mutillidae) of Japan

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Velvet ants of the tribe Smicromyrmini Bischoff (Hymenoptera: Mutillidae) of Japan

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Mutilla pustulata
Smith, 1873: 182
, ♂ , holotype ♂ (“Hiogo” [ Hyôgo ẍoi ], Honshû, Japan ) lost ( Mickel 1935 ). See Chen (1957) and Lelej (2005) for further synonymies.

Smicromyrme yakushimensis Yasumatsu, 1934
,
syn. nov.
: 65, ♀ , holotype ♀ (“Anbô-Funayuki” [ ẎƦ–ẘứ ], Yakushima Island, Japan ) [ELKU], examined;
Tsuneki 1972a: 20
, 25, ♀ ;
Yoshida 1989: 651
.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type material examined.
Smicromyrme yakushimensis Yasumatsu
: holotype , ♀ ( Figs 48 A–B, 49A–B, E, H), Anbô-Funayuki, Yakushima Island, Ôsumi Islands, Japan , 7.VIII.1929 , Hiroshi Hori leg. [ ELKU ].

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 49.
Neotrogaspidia pustulata
, ♀. A–B, E, H. Holotype,
Smicromyrme
yakushimensis
Yasumatsu
, ♀; C–D, F. ♀, Na- gano; G. ♀, Kôchi; A, C. mesosoma, dorsal view; B, D. metasoma, dorsal view; E–G. pygidial area; H. procoxa.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Remarks. The holotype of
Smicromyrme yakushimensis
has diagnostic characters of
Neotrogaspidia
listed above except that the setae are badly worn out and hardly recognizable. Direct comparison of this species with females of
N . pustulata
revealed that they are synonymous. The pygidial area of the holotype of
Sm . yakushimensis
is almost smooth as described by Yasumatsu (1934) ( Fig. 49E ), but this trait has also been observed in small individuals of
N . pustulata
( Fig. 49G ).

Lelej (1996a) described the genitalic volsella of
Neotrogaspidia
as lacking a paracuspis. This feature was also included in the key to Oriental genera of Trogaspidiini by Lelej (2005) to separate
Protrogaspidia Lelej, 1996
,
Nonveilleridia Lelej, 1996
and
Neotrogaspidia
from
Eotrogaspidia
and
Trogaspidia Ashmead, 1899
at couplet 7. Males collected in Japan , however, have a distinct tuberculate paracuspis ( Fig. 48F ). This character is therefore excluded from the key above. The definition of
Neotrogaspidia
, together with the genus placements of
N . hammeri ( Suárez, 1959 )
and
N . haemarrhoa ( Zavattari, 1914 )
, should be revised.
